articles.title: Scientists may have found dark matter after 100 years of searching
articles.summary: Nearly a century after astronomers first proposed dark matter to explain the strange motions of galaxies, scientists may finally be catching a glimpse of it. A University of Tokyo researcher analyzing new data from NASA’s Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope has detected a halo of high-energy gamma rays that closely matches what theories predict should be released when dark matter particles collide and annihilate. The energy levels, intensity patterns, and shape of this glow align strikingly well with long-standing models of weakly interacting massive particles, making it one of the most compelling leads yet in the hunt for the universe’s invisible mass.
articles.content:
In the early 1930s, Swiss astronomer Fritz Zwicky noticed that many galaxies were moving far faster than their visible mass should permit. This unusual motion led him to propose that some kind of invisible structure -- dark matter -- was supplying the extra gravitational pull needed to keep those galaxies intact. Nearly a century later, NASA's Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope may have captured the first direct evidence of this mysterious substance, offering the possibility of finally "seeing" dark matter.

Dark matter has remained one of astronomy's biggest unknowns since it was first suggested. Until now, scientists have only been able to study it indirectly by observing how it affects ordinary matter, such as the way it produces enough gravity to hold galaxies together. Direct detection has not been possible because dark matter particles do not interact with electromagnetic force -- meaning they do not absorb, reflect or emit light.

The WIMP Hypothesis and Predicted Gamma Rays

Many researchers believe that dark matter is made of weakly interacting massive particles, or WIMPs. These particles are thought to be heavier than protons and interact so weakly with normal matter that they are extremely difficult to detect. However, theory suggests that when two WIMPs collide, they annihilate each other and release energetic particles, including gamma ray photons.

Scientists have spent years examining regions where dark matter should be concentrated, especially the center of the Milky Way, searching for these specific gamma rays. Using new data from the Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope, Professor Tomonori Totani of the University of Tokyo now believes he has identified the predicted gamma ray signal associated with dark matter particle annihilation.

Totani's findings appear in the Journal of Cosmology and Astroparticle Physics.

A 20-GeV Gamma Ray Halo Near the Milky Way Center

"We detected gamma rays with a photon energy of 20 gigaelectronvolts (or 20 billion electronvolts, an extremely large amount of energy) extending in a halolike structure toward the center of the Milky Way galaxy. The gamma-ray emission component closely matches the shape expected from the dark matter halo," said Totani.

The measured gamma ray energy spectrum, which describes how the intensity of the emission varies, closely matches model predictions for the annihilation of hypothetical WIMPs with masses roughly 500 times that of a proton. The estimated frequency of these annihilation events based on the observed gamma ray intensity also fits within expected theoretical ranges.

Evaluating the Possibility of a Major Breakthrough

Totani explains that the gamma ray pattern cannot be easily matched to other known sources or more common astrophysical processes. Because of this, he views the data as a strong candidate for long-sought gamma ray emission from dark matter.

"If this is correct, to the extent of my knowledge, it would mark the first time humanity has 'seen' dark matter. And it turns out that dark matter is a new particle not included in the current standard model of particle physics. This signifies a major development in astronomy and physics," said Totani.

Next Steps and Independent Verification

Although Totani is confident in his analysis, he emphasizes that independent confirmation is essential. Other researchers will need to review the data to verify that the halolike radiation truly results from dark matter annihilation rather than another astrophysical source.

Further support could come from finding the same gamma ray signature in other regions rich in dark matter. Dwarf galaxies orbiting within the Milky Way halo are considered especially promising. "This may be achieved once more data is accumulated, and if so, it would provide even stronger evidence that the gamma rays originate from dark matter," said Totani.

Funding: This work was supported by JSPS/MEXT KAKENHI Grant Number 18K03692.

articles.personality_title: Scientists detect gamma rays that may reveal dark matter
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Dark matter is an invisible substance that makes up most of the universe’s mass. It was first suggested nearly 100 years ago to explain why galaxies move in strange ways. Until now, scientists have only seen its effects indirectly, since dark matter does not give off or reflect light.

**What happened** – A researcher from the University of Tokyo, Professor Tomonori Totani, studied new data from NASA’s Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope. He found a halo of high-energy gamma rays near the center of our galaxy. These gamma rays match the energy and pattern expected if dark matter particles, called WIMPs (weakly interacting massive particles), collide and destroy each other.

**Impact** – This discovery is important because it could be the first direct sign of dark matter, something scientists have been searching for almost a century. The gamma rays found fit very closely with what theories predicted about how dark matter should behave. If confirmed, it would mean finding a new kind of particle not yet known in physics.

**What's next step** – Other scientists will need to check this finding carefully to make sure the gamma rays really come from dark matter and not from another source. Researchers will also look for the same gamma ray signals in other places, like smaller galaxies near the Milky Way, to strengthen the proof.

**One-sentence takeaway** – New gamma ray data may provide the first direct evidence of dark matter, potentially changing our understanding of the universe.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des scientifiques détectent des rayons gamma qui pourraient révéler la matière noire
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La matière noire est une substance invisible qui compose la majeure partie de la masse de l’univers. Elle a été suggérée il y a près de 100 ans pour expliquer les mouvements étranges des galaxies. Jusqu’à présent, les scientifiques n’en ont vu les effets que de manière indirecte, car la matière noire n’émet ni ne réfléchit la lumière.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Un chercheur de l’Université de Tokyo, le professeur Tomonori Totani, a étudié de nouvelles données du télescope spatial à rayons gamma Fermi de la NASA. Il a découvert un halo de rayons gamma très énergétiques près du centre de notre galaxie. Ces rayons correspondent à l’énergie et au modèle attendus si les particules de matière noire, appelées WIMPs (particules massives faiblement interagissantes), entrent en collision et s’annihilent.

**Impact** – Cette découverte est importante car elle pourrait être la première preuve directe de la matière noire, que les scientifiques cherchent depuis presque un siècle. Les rayons gamma trouvés correspondent très précisément aux prévisions théoriques sur le comportement de la matière noire. Si cela est confirmé, cela signifierait la découverte d’un nouveau type de particule inconnue en physique.

**Prochaine étape** – D’autres scientifiques devront vérifier cette découverte pour s’assurer que les rayons gamma proviennent bien de la matière noire et non d’une autre source. Ils chercheront aussi les mêmes signaux dans d’autres endroits, comme des petites galaxies proches de la Voie lactée, pour renforcer la preuve.

**En une phrase** – De nouvelles données sur des rayons gamma pourraient fournir la première preuve directe de la matière noire, changeant potentiellement notre compréhension de l’univers.
articles.personality_title_es: Científicos detectan rayos gamma que podrían revelar la materia oscura
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La materia oscura es una sustancia invisible que forma la mayor parte de la masa del universo. Se propuso hace casi 100 años para explicar los movimientos extraños de las galaxias. Hasta ahora, los científicos solo han visto sus efectos de manera indirecta, porque la materia oscura no emite ni refleja luz.

**Qué pasó** – Un investigador de la Universidad de Tokio, el profesor Tomonori Totani, analizó nuevos datos del telescopio espacial de rayos gamma Fermi de la NASA. Encontró un halo de rayos gamma de alta energía cerca del centro de nuestra galaxia. Estos rayos coinciden con la energía y el patrón que se esperan si las partículas de materia oscura, llamadas WIMPs (partículas masivas débilmente interactuantes), chocan y se aniquilan.

**Impacto** – Este hallazgo es importante porque podría ser la primera señal directa de la materia oscura, que los científicos han buscado durante casi un siglo. Los rayos gamma encontrados encajan muy bien con lo que las teorías predicen sobre cómo debería comportarse la materia oscura. Si se confirma, significaría encontrar un nuevo tipo de partícula desconocida hasta ahora en la física.

**Próximo paso** – Otros científicos deberán revisar este descubrimiento para asegurarse de que los rayos gamma provienen realmente de la materia oscura y no de otra fuente. También buscarán la misma señal en otros lugares, como galaxias pequeñas cerca de la Vía Láctea, para fortalecer la evidencia.

**Resumen en una frase** – Nuevos datos de rayos gamma podrían ofrecer la primera evidencia directa de la materia oscura, cambiando posiblemente nuestra comprensión del universo.
